>>9648516

https://boingboing.net/2019/11/18/horace-goes-copyright-striking.html

One example I can think of is Paul Andrews, who is part of a few companies like Retro Games Ltd and Subvert. Responsible for some re-releases of Lynx and microcomputer games. He seems to have made whatever pittance of a licensing agreement you need to with whatever legacy publisher notionally owns some relevant (but not very scrutinized) rights to some random old ZX Spectrum and C64 games which are not exactly hot commodities. You know, for the license to republish, maybe issue a "remake".

One of the more notable examples of this is that his company/companies "own" the rights to the Horace games on ZX Spectrum. A few years back he went on a tear, launching copyright takedowns for anything featuring Horace that he didn't like, including videos by some YouTuber whose content he felt "undermined Horace's family-friendly image." Further scrutiny suggests that the actual rights are murky at best far more limited than he suggests, meaning he likely doesn't even have the right to copyright strike anything. But hey, it's Horace, who's gonna put the money in to litigate against that?

>>9639518
So I went and tried it out side by side, both with the same composite out > VCR > TV chain and switching back and forth between AV1 and AV2, and the aspect ratio is the same, the PS3 is slightly lower for some reason (this just comes up because I was lining them up in TT's options menu and I had to go -1 on the PS2), and at least in TT some static screens like the Sony Computer Entertainment America Presents screen shake like a bastard but that's probably a CPU emulation issue I guess? The general thing though is that even in the XMB this PS3's composite output seems to be slightly sharper in principle, but generates rainbow artifacts like a motherfucker. Even with the Cross Color Reduction Filter in the options enabled specifically to tone it down there's noticeable red/blue bleed on black to white transitions that doesn't happen on PS2. I'm thinking they're outputting a more raw picture on purpose to try to make small text and stuff for HD games more readable on outdated displays at the cost of being ugly on TVs that aren't good at fixing it themselves.

tl;dr, my PS3's composite output is gross. But playing PS2 games on PS3 with component seems like it would be daijoubu.

I don't think that's strictly true. On PS3 it depends on the game and whether the developer set up support for 480p/i rendering. If they didn't, then yes, it gets downscaled from 720p, just as it would get upscaled to 1080p if that's not supported. In practice, IIRC, earlier games had 480i support whereas later games didn't bother because standard/enhanced def was mostly a dead meme by that point.

NTA but do you have any recommendations from personal experience? Because everybody cares about and documents the converters the other way around, but never the HDMI *to* composite ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641885
I have been milling about looking at various converters, the only good ones tend be from smaller hobbyist shops that are annoying to acquire easily.

Say you serious and are building a media PC dedicated for a CRT i think the best way to go about it is start with an older AMD GPU(15 bucks on ebay) that has DVI-I or VGA outputs then to converter then to your TV. The reason to use an older AMD GPU is because theres a driver on windows that will do resolution switching between 240p and 480i modes and all sorts of various CRT related settings that makes things work more authentically. This is an almost essential feature when dealing with an an older retro emulator machine because sprites start looking blurry without the proper 240p scanlines

HDMI does not play nicely with CRT from various CRT groups ive read, i think its because theres a floor of how low of a resolution HDMI can go down to which fucks with pixel scaling or some shit. Its just something to avoid whenever possible.

>How does Arcade games on a CRT work?
Perfectly fine.
> is there any limitations on what you can do on a consumer CRT in terms of arcade resolutions?
If it is a 24hz or 31khz arcade game then you will need a CRT that supports those resolutions. Something like a multisync monitor from NEC or Mitsubishi. 31hz is widely supported on basically any PC CRT monitor since it is similar to 640x480 vga.
>Can you even rotate consumer CRTs to play TATE without damaging them?
Yes, no problems.

LCD and OLEDs do not usually have a glass screen. So there would not be "glass in front of glass". There would be only one layer of glass.

>>9647927
n64 only outputs s-video at the highest, so if you want that, then sure, get something with s-video in. you could also rgb mod the n64 or use a clone console or a mister or something to get rgb output (any cable that plugs into the back of the back of the n64 is working with s-video to start out with, even if it outputs rgb). if you do get rgb output, then you can (probably) rgb mod the tv you have already. you might even be able to s-video mod it since it has the vcr. not sure, i only took a cursory look at the service manual. pvms (sony or otherwise) sometimes have rgb in, but not always. usually at least s-video (y/c) though. pvms do have a sharper picture than consumer sets, and that might make a difference sometimes, but anything over 600 TVL won't make a difference if i'm doing my math right based on the n64's 773.5 dots per line. that's probably higher than your tv, i don't see it listed in the specs. it doesn't matter that much anyway. the biggest factor is the input. composite to s-video is the biggest jump in quality from personal experience. no matter what input you use though, the fact is that the n64 only outputs 240p. things like a framemeister can upscale the video signal but upscaling can't add detail, only diminish it. if you really want to be able to see things better, then emulate and render at a higher resolution.

posts.com: There's a weird debate about this game ongoing for the last twenty years and people just sort of talk past each other about it. People like it because it's calm and contemplative, and sort of like the gaming equivalent of listening to ambient music. It's atmospheric and the simplicity of the gameplay and flawed controls/extremely minimal HUD is questionably a feature rather than a defect. I don't really care much about the technicals, I just like it because i like wandering, and the expanse of the game gives the sense of a believable but foreign world--like a waking dream. If you find the controls irritating to the degree that it makes you question why people like this, that makes sense to me too. It's just a matter of preference.

>>9641319
The only similarities I can see are that they're fantasy games with mysterious plots and depict the ruins of a Western civilisation with a kind of alien feel to it. King's Field IV came out first and already had a weird, bleak, interconnected fantasy setting with strange and depressed NPCs scattered around that all had lines that would fit seamlessly into any Dark Souls game.

The nature of the mystery elements is also pretty different, in SotC things are mysterious because you're told almost nothing about the setting, whereas Souls games have a ton of flavour text and dialogue containing cryptic references to figures and events you have no context for, almost begging you to try and connect the dots. In SotC you're hardly given any dots to connect.

Even then I think you could argue this mystery element wasn't quite as strong in Demon's Souls anyway and only really took off in Dark Souls. If you just want to say that SotC inspired them to switch to third-person, maybe, but in that case I'd argue SotC's contribution was pretty minor.

posts.com: I want to get into dungeon RPGs. Do you have any advice for drawing maps? I'm going to start with Phantasy Star on the Master System and I've heard that the dungeons in that game aren't overly complex. What do you do when you run out of room because you're close to the edge of the page? Do you continue onto a second sheet and tape them together?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I use Excel. Make square cells, then right click, cell format, borders. It's a bit annoying to have to select border every time, however it's still the fastest solution I have found even compared to programs dedicated for this sort of things.

The only drawback is that you can't directly draw on the map, so when there are things like one-sided doors or walls I have to write notes within the cells; not as good as drawing an arrow.

Anyway if your RPG doesn't have too many buttons, this way you can have the pad in your left hand (using L/R for the 2 main buttons), and map in Excel with the right hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finished the first Wizardry these days and the way i went for, was just to do it all on paper. Frankly, i think this is the ideal way to do it. Using excel might be somewhat good as the other anon described, but as he also said, there are a few disadvantages. Doing on paper doesn't require alt-tabbing or moving the mouse, right-clicking and inserting something; drawing the lines with a pencil for me is much faster and more efficient. There's also the fact that you can draw symbols on the tiles which is almost a must for games like this (typing text there is good too, but not as fast). pencil and paper is more soulful, also

I recommend printing out a few sheets of graph paper you can find on google and getting a hardcover notebook or something so you can draw on it in front of the PC or TV. I finished the floors almost entirely with tiny blue grid sheets, but then i found out these dotted ones like pic related are better as you can see the wall lines more clearly.

>What do you do when you run out of room because you're close to the edge of the page? Do you continue onto a second sheet and tape them together?
You gotta be aware of how large the dungeons are in the game that you're playing. Most old DRPG's don't have ones that extend too much to the sides, although you may consider using grids with more space if there are a lot of floors and you don't wanna use too much paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I use a custom grid set up in Paint, color coding as I map. Green for explored squares, black for walls, red for doors, with one-way doors being red on one side and black on the other. Then you just pick other colors as you encounter new features. Works great.

Nice thread, I love games where you're encouraged to keep notes and draw maps outside the game. I like using regular graph paper notebooks. There's triangle grid paper too you could buy or print for hexagonal tile maps or isometric maps, but for most maps regular square graph paper is good.

If I need more space I continue on a second sheet. I don't usually tape them, but that sounds fun if you have room for it. And if the map goes up or down a floor I usually use a whole new sheet for that too and match up the stairway/passage to the same square on both papers.

I assume that the translators assumed the name was supposed to be GrandVALE instead of BELL because In Japanese there's no v sound so English names/words with v in them, that sound is replaced by a b sound. Similar to how l sounds get replaced with r sounds. That assumption often leads to names that really were supposed to be "Rhineford" as "Lineford" or Asparas as Aspallas. The same thing happens with v and b as well.

>>9639537
inaccurate; The designer was instructed to make the console more trendy and less toy-like. The design was also changed so that no one would try putting liquid containers on top of it; NoA had to repair a number of NES units that had been used as tables for drinks, cereal bowls, soda cans, etc. This was a big part of redesigning the sufami so that no one would think of putting drinks on top of an SNES.

If you're angry about the design changes then at least know the correct reasons for them. The designer's opinion mattered little in the design change, for one thing. If you want to be angry at anyone, be angry at the bigwigs of NoA at the time, like Howard Lincoln or Minoru Arakawa.

Article starts on page 44 in case you're curious. https://archive.org/details/NintendoPowerVolume25/page/n43/mode/2up

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646847
It means you compose four 8x8 pixel images into a 16x16 pixel image, referring to each of the four as linear index like 0, 1, 2, 3.

So for example, metatile 0 might be made of
0: 1,2, 8, 9

where 1 refers to the image of a flower, 2 some grass, and 8 and 9 dirt.

OP here, the current workflow I'm testing out uses the following:

- A tileset image of 8x8 pixel tiles using only rgb colors 0, 85, 170, 255, with 8 rows and 8 columns for a total of 64 tiles
- A Tiled tileset made in Tiled (free program) using this tileset. Just import and save.
- A Tiled tilemap using this tileset. This one defines the metatiles. Just arrange them how you like, but I like 8 rows and 8 columns of 16x16 pixel blocks. 64 metatiles is the max in the current scheme.
- Then your level as a tilemap, importing the tilemap above as a tileset of 16x16 pixel tiles. This should be one gameboy screen in dimensions, then expanding horizontally or vertically.

Tiled is a really nice editor. I think we could use it for enemy and item placement too.

Hellfire is an expansion pack for the original Diablo that was not developed by the original team. Sierra, the publisher, wanted to get more use from their publishing rights so they had one of their studios produce the expansion in Blizzard's stead.
It adds some neat things (oils, running in town) and extends the life of the game but the content is generally not as good as the base game.

In the case of D1 it's because the hardest levels, in terms of monster spawns and enemy group composition, are completely full of projectile spam enemies that run away. For Rogue and Sorcerer this is rough but doable. The more dangerous enemies are the hell knights and possibly getting swarmed by the lightning serpents but that is pretty manageable with kiting. By the time you reach Hell you should have gotten a hold of how to deal with these things..

For Warrior though it's just getting fucked. Succubi run away at the same speed you move at and being weak with both magic and bows means your options for dealing with them are really limited. Getting Teleport is your best bet but you have no guarantee of getting both enough +magic gear and a book for it in the same run. What's worse is the block stun animation can trap you if too many Succubi are firing at once. In spite of them fleeing they are no slouch in a fight either, those fireballs add up quick.

Also fighting the hell sorcerers is a straight up fucking nightmare.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9646641
The sound effects shit on those of any game made today. Every enemy has intensely evocative noises for every attack and death.

The music is S tier. Nothing you would ever listen to outside the game, but it's creepy as fuck and builds the atmosphere on its own. Tristram's theme is insane. Peaceful but uneasy. No idea how the hell he accomplished that.

The slow move speed and your low relative power level (you are a dude, with a sword) reinforce the feeling of dread and helplessness.

The townsfolk are given enough personality to feel like real people.

It's a horror game before it's a Diablo-like. I find D2 way more fun and replayable, but D1 shits on it in terms of atmosphere.

Everything in it works in synergy with everything else. There's no clash between the music, art, and game styles.

posts.com:
You have to look at the DACs specifically, the actual converter chips. Some are better than others despite what James Randi fans will tell you. Then you have to look at the supporting circuitry.

Lots of people like external DACs because they're simply located farther away from the RF noisy environment in your computer. This sounds good in theory but if the driver's one of those shitty class D amps (it probably is) or even a more upscale AB amp, and your sound card has a class A amplifier, the sound card will reproduce the waveform better.

posts.sub: How would YOU fix the sega saturn?
posts.com:
As we all know, sega sharturn was a piece of shart that made sega bleed money, but could it have been designed differently? Here's my take.
>CPU:
1x Hitachi SH-2 @28MHz, maybe just simply grab the 23Mhz one from the 32X because this crap is hindered by 16-bit ISA anyway.
>GPU:
Geometry DSP optimized for maximum flat shaded polygon performance. Get rid of all the other functions and try to reach 1 million flat shaded polygon per second.
A simple VDP that only draws backdrop image and transform sprites vertically and horizontally for use in 2.5D games.
>co-processor:
8 MHz 68000 handling the CD and background music.
>Sound:
Genesis FM sound chip directly connected to hitachi SH-2 to produce sfx.
4 channel PCM sound chip similar to amiga paula to minimize production cost, handled by 68000 chip, intended to stream audio data from the CD or play protracker background music.
>RAM
1.5MB main RAM, 256K framebuffer.
>CD format
0.75x speed (100KB/s) CD drive to let it make use of cheap flimsy parts without breaking down constantly
50MB micro-CD for minimum seek time and cheaper cost.
Copy protection ASIC.
>retail price
$160 bucks
no more than 30 bucks for a game

>performance figure
1 million flat shaded polygons per second, all games ported into this machine will be entirely flat shaded.
120fps games with 84,000 polygons per frame, faster than the PS1 and N64 could ever dream to be.
Ugly but fast and complex games The epitome of fuck what everyone else thinks: the console..

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There really wasn't a good solution in 1994 for the Saturn. They could have made a scaled down version of the Model 2, but that system was very expensive to produce, so the end result would have probably been rather crippled. Just a few years later they would have had their pick of 3D chipsets to choose from, but 1994 was still the first-gen 3D stuff that was all custom. The only hope they would have is to brew up a cheap custom 3D chipset, or keep the Genesis alive with either the Sega CD or 32X until '96 and make a console around a Voodoo chipset.
1994 was just a rough time to create a next generation console. Everyone thought throwing a CD-ROM drive and some decent hardware together would solve everything. See 3DO, CD-i, all the CD-ROM add-ons. While the PS1 was successful in the endeavor, it still had a number of flaws like the lack of a z-buffer since there just wasn't any standards for 3D hardware yet.
SEGA was in a funny spot. They could bring out a next-gen console and get the drop on Nintendo like they did with the Genesis, or they could wait for better hardware they didn't know was coming.

It has some good 2D games. For gen 1 either the Super GameBoy on the SNES or Pokemon Stadium with the Transfer PAK on the N64.

For gen 2, GBC, SGB or Transfer Pak. Gold and Silver look great on the SGB, but if you want to play Crystal on the TV, you'll need the Transfer Pak.

PS. The SGB has a hidden fast speed setting, similar to Doduo/Dodrio mode in Stadium, but you need a special SNES controller to access it.

PPS. Also worth noting, if you have a GBC, is that there's two interesting hacks for gen 1 games: one adds full color to them, the second adds better sprites from gen 2. You'll have a fully colored gen 1 experience that feels fresh, but you cannot use them hacks with a mono GB, SGB or Game Boy Tower in Stadium sadly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

My point is that the game forces you into a very narrow "problem-solving" approach both in map layout, units given and so on... certain units are specifically designated to defeat certain opponents and you almost always have to use them that way.

In "true" tactics games like XCOM or Tactics Ogre you are given a far more broad approach in dealing with situations tactically, rather than treating levels/battles as problems to solve a very specific way.

>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
idk much about racers ne we liked them desu but RR4 pulled me in i guess aesthetically. heard the theme and gave it a try. the aesthetic is cool, the tracks aren’t crazy, but do have a nice feel, i especially love the three night time stages. the interfaces, menus, music, and character portraits all have this energetic yet still laidback feel, captures that cowboy bebop or ray crisis combo of badass action with lively jazz going on. the drifting is easy and intuitive, i like how especially as a beginner you can catch on quickly, however the levels get more punishing of your mistakes. just as gilbert says by the end you’ll be trying to run the perfect race. speaking of gilbert one thing that really set R4 apart from every other racing game for me were the stories they’re nothing too deep, but they’re fun, simple, and the two middle ones, ESPECIALLY the PRC story do enough to grip you just enough to add a story motivation to the fun gameplay. that’s what captured me, but lll expose myself and say i’m a complete outsider. hydro thunder, NFS: HP, GT II, Wipeout, TOCA, i don’t play any of those shits, so maybe R4 is just the most accessible in that way. oh and most of the OST kicks ass

TLDR: cool ass menus, music, simple but serviceable characters, easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master gameplay, but im less than a noob to racers, so take it with a grain of salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Capacitors are known for being leaky on the original XBox, check if inside of yours stinks and has dried goop on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Bad caps on Xbox do cause some bizarre issues. One example for me was controllers working intermittently. I plugged/unplugged the controller too many times and a cap popped in front of my eyes (with the case off).
Replacing the main caps on Xbox is an easy solder project for a beginner so I would recommend it.
Check your cable as well though.

Arbok gets glare, which is at least interesting. Plenty of options for poison for blue, not missing out. Sandshrew however is the best ground type pokemon in gen 1. Unless you go for speed abuse dugtrio. Cubone is solid too, but you get sandshrew earlier and it's better, so the winner Blue

Primeape is 2nd best fighting type in the game, getting one early in the game can be nice, persian is also possibly the 2nd best normal type, and has crit abuse and a great movepool so Tie.

Arcanine has fat stats, Ninetales has a few interesting moves, both fire, not really missing out over the other here another Tie

Pinsir vs Scyther, well, neither provide a counter to psychic. If we allow wing attack from yellow into play Scyther is the clear winner, otherwise its mostly a tie, but Id still edge scyther the winner since gets swords dance and such. So Red

Electabuzz and magmar both do the same thing. Just electric vs fire. I can't really call a winner here, so another tie. You don't get them in the same place, which is also interesting. One is in an area part of the main story, the other is not, but no major flaw or advantage on either.

Ultimately, red wins. I'll point out, if you want a grass type and you pick charmander or squirtle and play blue, you're fucked on grass, because bellsprout really sucks, petal dance vileplume is way better. Basically, scyther and vileplume clinch it for red. It's actually pretty balanced how they split it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its interesting how all three starters have different playstyles that all manage to have different pros and cons so that none of them truly feel hard if you play different ways. even beyond the "Bulbasaur resists the first three gyms, Charmander is weak to the first 2(possibly 3 if you grind him to Charizard before Lt. surge)
Bulbasaur is great for defensive and stat changing/stalling play. Just the fact that he reissts a lot of common types and has a big spongey HP makes him perfect for the typical G1 grind method of "weak Pokemon first turn, then switch". also has a surprisingly high Special/attack, which means it can hold its own.Just solid for learning game mechanics.
Squirtle is a nice balanced middle ground between defense, special and attack, learns the biggest variety of moves and can cover most types buy itself.
Charmander feels the easiest to grind with because so much of what you encounter are bug types and Pokemon witha weak special stat ; while his attack/special aren't actually higher than the Bulbasaur line his move pool centers more around stronger attacks early on. Feels geared towards players who just want to use damaging moves.

You can beat the game largely with just one of any of them, sure, but I'd say Bulbasaur is the easiest to build a team around early on, Charmander is good for grinding through the early game if you just want to muscle through with attacks until you can take advantage of mid game Pokemon that become available, and Squirtle is best if you largely want to focus on one -three Pokemon. But you can easily use Charmander to solo the game, or Squirtle to build a team around.
Personally, when I want to not use a starter I usually go with Charmander to grind through with ember, get a nidoran as a support until I can lean more on him and get to Cerulean and have access to all the Pokemon around there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I actually first learned to program in 1985, by reading the BASIC manual that came with my computer.
The internet existed in the 80s, but until around 1992 it wasn't really available to the general public. We had Compuserve and BBSes (with Fidonet and other networks) that we used to ask questions and trade tutorials around. And books, of course. There were a lot more bookstores back then, even some stores devoted entirely to computer books.
Programming *is* a lot easier now. Back then all we had was BASIC, assembly, C, and Pascal, on slow processors with tiny amounts of memory. Now we have Rust, Javascript, Python, etc which are all (each in their own way) easier languages, with much faster processors (multiple processors even!), and more memory than we know what to do with. Plus Google and Stack Overflow, IDEs with autocomplete and refactoring, and copious free libraries that do everything for you short of sucking your dick.
In fact, these days I am regularly astonished by the ignorance and stupidity of so many younger programmers. People who barely have the intellectual power to tie their shoes are capable of producing programs that would have taken a genius back in the day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9645864
>I've played PC and console shooters and there is practically no difference except control method
The control method does define some key things, but I'm coming from the angle of believing console FPS games are superior to PC FPS games.

Aiming isn't very interesting. Play enough shooters and the realization you're just pointing at pixels and tapping them until they fold is enough to make you equate shooter skill with your skill at navigating windows explorer. Many PC shooters are designed around this, and honestly it doesn't do much for me anymore. Sure I still play Insurgency (source) a few times a week mostly because the last few servers have great people on it that are a ton of fun to play with. I'm under no delusion that the gameplay itself is shallow as it can be, I point, I click, and if the game (and server agree) I clicked best and killed the other guy.

Then there's console shooters, of which the key complaint for literal decades from PC gamers has been "sticks aren't good for aiming." To which I think most developers agree. I agree. I don't really like aiming anyway, give me an alternative. The best FPS games on consoles do this. Either fun weapons that behave in ways that bypass the need for aiming but tap into movement or spatial mechanics, lock on systems like in HL1 on the PS2 that still augment better movement and give opportunity for expressions of skill. Time Splitters 3's fun enemy engagements and variety of weapons, Power Slave's elaborate encounters and interesting choice of gear that swiftly veers from the stereotypical.

The focus on diverting gameplay from aiming brought some peoples favorites (like metroid prime, to me the game was too boring,) inspired devs to rethink melee, vehicles, health/armor in Halo, and shit, the proper way to play Doom on PC is to not aim vertically, making the player feel like a ball pinging around arenas schucking demons full of pellets.

I think that gets my point across, console FPS games are more fun.

if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

>>9625207
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs
i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing so you don't have to worry about bringing them down, and if you're worried about night missions you can usually wait a few hours before actually sending your skyranger in.
i usually don't even consider shooting down ufos until i'm confident my main base(s) can handle an attack, i have plasma beams and the aliens start spamming more missions, maybe they're infiltrating germany and i don't want half a dozen ufos tanking my score during a particularly bad month, or maybe i'm being cheeky and i want to nuke a terror ship in january or something. ymmv

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9631206
>i'm not nearly as experienced with tftd so i can't really provide input on it
It's generally similar with the following important differences

>aliens will do shipping route attacks starting in April--these can have any alien race on them
>artifact sites will start appearing in July--these are always a Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew, and you cannot duck out of them due to a massive point penalty (-1000 points for failing to complete the mission, -3000 for ignoring it).
>the game will generate 12 artifact sites, one for each region of the globe
>colonies are always Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew in part 1 and Lobstermen in part 2, but the race that constructed the colony will send supply ships to it
>on lower difficulty settings you will get more port/island attacks and fewer shipping route/artifact sites
>in infiltration missions, none of the alien infiltration fleet lands--until you get advanced craft weapons you will not be able to shoot down most of the USOs
>the TFTD terror ship (Battleship) has more powerful weapons than the battleship (Dreadnought) so while you could easily shoot down a EU Terror Ship with two Interceptors+Avalanche missiles, it's extremely risky (but still possible) to attempt it in TFTD--since it also never lands, the only way to fight one is to shoot it down
>in base defense missions, up to 5 aliens will spawn inside your base
>the Barracuda has shorter range than Interceptor and can't fly as far before running out of fuel

another little pointer is that when fighting landed or crashed UFOs there's a certain probability that aliens will spawn inside the ship or outside of it. this depends on their rank, but generally:

>soldier 50% chance
>engineer 30% chance
>medic 30% chance
>navigator 10% chance
>leader/commander 0% chance (they're always inside on the bridge)

this is why sometimes you find a UFO jammed full of aliens like a clown car and other times it's only got a few inside

>>9631206
>i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/MISSIONS.DAT

Most UFOs on most missions land except during retaliation. Small scouts only land during base construction or harvest missions (small scout #1 on harvest missions lands, #2 doesn't). The first terror ship on terror missions does not land either. Shooting a UFO down of course may spawn a retaliation mission, which is a 50% chance of occuring either in the region the shootdown was in or the region where the X-COM craft that shot it down is based. If a retaliation scout passes over your base, it may become revealed to the aliens, and the odds go up the more facilities the base has.

If you shoot down the Battleship attacking the base with an X-COM craft, or they don't find your base at all, the retaliation mission ends. If the aliens do attack and you beat them in a base defense mission, the retaliation mission is immediately restarted with a new Small Scout and they'll keep going for it until they fail to find your base or you shoot down the incoming Battleship. if you shoot it down with base defense weapons it produces the infamous bug with endlessly attacking Battleships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638543
If you're fighting a Battleship, the commander is on the bridge and will usually be carrying a Blaster Launcher, although early game it's more likely Heavy Plasma. In alien bases he always carries Heavy Plasma and will be in the central command room, though on Superhuman he'll spawn outside someplace due to lack of spawn nodes and it can be real hard to identify him without a Mind Probe.

Weapon loadouts for base defense missions are same as the Battleship, meaning the commander will likely have a Blaster Launcher, although he can spawn anywhere and again be very hard to identify without a Mind Probe. It's generally easiest to capture one from a Battleship as you can guarantee he'll always be on the bridge.

Note that you will also need a live alien leader to complete the research tree for Cydonia or Bust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battleships are easy to clear since you can just shoot up the central grav lift at aliens above and if you have Blaster Bombs, you can also fire them up there. Beware that aliens will fire Blaster Bombs down the grav lift at you as well. In the original games you could shoot a ranged weapon up the lifts to easily pick off aliens on the floor above you, but OXC makes it that the aliens can also shoot down the lifts at you which they used to not be able to do.

Also note the room I marked with an X. That room has a spawn node, and the large-sized terrorists (Reaper, Cyberdisc, and Sectopod) can spawn in there and get stuck and unable to leave. For the latter two you can be in for a nasty surprise when you go into that room and one of them is in there and facing you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You'll want to eventually get psionics, and the best way to do this is to bag a Sectoid leader from a larger UFO. Of course he'll be mind raping you the entire mission but...about mind control. It depends on line of sight. The aliens can only target soldiers they can see, and they'll always attack the weakest soldier that is visible to them. This is why different soldiers will be targeted at different times.

When you have a Psy Lab built, you can put up to 10 soldiers in it to train them, but this will take a month during which time they're effectively out of action (you can still use them on missions but why are you putting them in harm's way?) At first you just want to determine what soldiers have good psionic strength and which ones are crap. The good ones you may leave in the Psy Lab for additional months to build their psionic skills while the shitty ones can be used against non-psionic aliens. Or you can just take them into action and practice on aliens--each attempt at mind control counts towards your psy skill; doesn't have to succeed, just the attempt is enough. While taking over Floaters and Mutons is easy, the tougher aliens need a much stronger team.

When you go to Cydonia, make sure all soldiers have a minimum of 60 psionic strength and really, you want 80 or more.

>>9619851
The problem is that the tech tree in TFTD is bugged.
If you don't research certain items in a specific order, the game becomes unwinnable as you will not be able to unlock essential techs required to win the game.
To compound matters, there are two different versions of TFTD with slightly different tech trees (and different bugs associated with them).
It's positively rage inducing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used a map editor to check and it turns out the map packs for OXC have all the alien spawn nodes intact so aliens should spawn in your base in TFTD properly. Maybe I just got a weird randomizer roll the last time I did a base defense. Also guess what else? The OXC map packs changed the tile properties to get rid of bugs that let you grenade aliens through UFO outer hulls.

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/Explosions#Hacking_HE_versus_Walls

Basically, the walls in question here (anything not a north or west wall) originally had their "Block" value set to 0 so although you cannot actually destroy them short of a Blaster Bomb, they do not block explosions. OXC's map packs simply set their "Block" value to 100 to remove this exploit.

Some glitches in the TFTD maps were also fixed for example you used to be able to blow up USO entrance doors with a Sonic Pulser but their armor value was changed to 80 (the max damage a SP will do to terrain at the epicenter of the explosion is 60).

While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

>>9643348
The source is me checking the game code coupled with existing dissassembly and documentation to help (though I don't trust the dissassembly too much because external docs that come with it talk about things which aren't in the game at all, must be a romhack or something)

Example, Big Slug data in the Japanese version
08 00 03 01 04 0B 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

Big Slug data in the US version
08 00 03 02 03 09 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

So on top of the exp given being changed from 01 to 02 (already a known thing easily checked by playing or checking guides), the attack value was changed from 0B to 09, losing 2 points.

Pretty much every enemy has changes like that, some more substantial than that too.

I'll document it all one of these days, but it takes time; and I intend to check up on other things too like probability for enemies to use this or that spell or to drop items etc

>>9643352
>know more than the devs

The "we didn't have time to properly test and balance the game" excuse was from a Japanese interview, thus talking about the Japanese version. One should also take into account that they spent one month and a half (november/december 1986) doing nothing but debugging and balancing the game. That's a lot of time. The game was delayed for that purpose specifically.
The fact is, making RPGs hard and require grinding was a norm then, which as a whole gradually decreased with time (and the US version is from 1990, thus the adjustements)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just checked the code (again, US NES version) and whenever Gold Batboons attempts to do Sacrifice, it checks its remaining HP and compares it to value 1C, which equals 28 in decimal; and proceeds to fuck off if the value is higher.
28 being 25% of 112, the Gold Batboon's max HP value when it spawns (as stated HP may vary), so it's not really 25% of its health, but 25% of its max possible health.

One interesting thing I'm not sure I fully understand however is that if you have 2 Gold Batboons, it checks both enemies HP values. I *think* what happens is that Gold Batboon A may very well be the one to use Sacrifice if Gold Batboon B is the one with low HP; not that the player will know because he will be kill.

Honestly it just seems like basic RPG playing to me before auto-targetting became a thing

Fun fact: the gold values are tied to the HP values, so if the enemy has -10% of its max HP value you'll get -10% of its max gold value

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642249
I'm inclined to think you've got multiple memories blended together. U.N. Squadron is indeed a horizontal shmup and I don't think it was a part of any further game series. The title in Japan is Area 88, and it was a game based on a manga series of the same name running at the time.
I do have another suspicion. The cabinet could have been repurposed. The cheapest way to do so would be with a game that runs on the same board. Area 88 ran off a CPS-1 board. For vertical shmups on a CPS-1, that would mean the actual game was either 1941 or Varth: Operation Thunderstorm. Look up some gameplay on those to see if they ring any bells.
I don't have much confidence in my knowledge on arcade hardware so if anyone knows I've said something wrong, let me know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Both are great
The GCN library is way the fuck deeper than the N64
It was also an era where Nintendo was doing a bunch of weird and interesting things with their IPs, so you got stuff like Metroid Prime, Mario Strikers, Luigi's Mansion, WarioWare and then new IPs like Pikmin and Eternal Darkness
On top of that you got Animal Crossing and Fire Emblem representation in the west, and significantly better third party support over the N64.

So to me it's like, yeah if I picked the top 5 games of the N64 to go head to head with the top 5 games from the GCN, the N64 would probably come out on top. But the sheer weight of the GCN's library pretty handily puts it on top over the N64 overall.

It's funny though I've been a Gamecube supporter since it launched, I bought FE: Path of Radiance and Paper Mario TTYD on launch, I was one of the poor bastards who had to wait an extra month to play Twilight Princess because I wasn't super interested in the Wii. So take that all into account when I say: I think the recent deification of the Gamecube is a massive over correction. It was an awesome console at the time and I don't think it deserved to be as eclipsed by the PS2 as it was, but holy FUCK do people put it up on a pedestal these days.

>>9633014
I got SM64 Christmas 96 and OoT in fall of 98 with my allowance, so yes I was there. I'm not saying they're bad games, I'm saying from a more objective perspective they aren't revolutionary. Virtually no games copied the SM64 camera frankly a good thing, everyone was copying the Quake and Tomb Raider cameras instead and things evolved from there. Z-targeting in OoT was a nice evolution for melee, but that's all it was. Z-targeting without movement was already in Megaman Legends, and Z-targeting with movement was already in Tomb Raider, so all OoT did was adapt it for melee with relative direction inputs. Again, a nice evolution, but obviously not revolutionary.

>>9632901
N64 was my favorite console since 1996. However I’ve been playing the Gamecube a lot since last year and noticed that a lot of the N64 games I loved have Gamecube sequels and ports, some better some worse. Let’s look at the list of the best N64 games:

>Ocarina of Time
- Ported, with a bonus master quest version
>Majora’s Mask
- Ported
>Mario Kart 64
- Sequel (Double Dash) is better
> Super Smash Bros
- Sequel (Melee) is better
>Goldeneye & Perfect Dark
- Timesplitters 2 is almost as good, plus you get Timesplitters 3 and you also get 5 James Bond games
>Rogue Squadron
- sequel is better
>Super Mario 64
- sequel is not as good, good enough though
>San Francisco Rush
- ported

Anyways, you pretty much get an at least decent followup, if not better version, of every great N64 game.

On top of this you have, with a Gameboy Player, access to 3 Gameboy generations, and through that ports of the best NES and SNES games (and that’s not even counting the compilations)

And on too of all that, you get RE4 and Metroid Prime 1&2

I can’t believe I’m saying this, but the Gamecube really is the better console. The amount of Zelda, Resident Evil, Sonic, Mega Man, and Mario games you can play on that thing is just mind blowing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647357
As far as I understand, it's pretty much just one guy doing this in his spare time, he doesn't even have financial incentive.
Also the game was originally made with Adobe Flash, but everything was dropped once Adobe announced they wouldn't support Flash anymore.

Other than that, the scope of the game is just ridiculous.
There's pretty much no recycled assets from the original games.
3 different playable characters, with significantly different playstyle, intro stages and personal nemesis.
Intro stage + 8 stages + 6 open areas + "viral" stage + 5 fortress stages.
Stages have different conditions/weather.
Harder version of the stages after you have beaten 4 of the mavericks.
Also enemy/boss patterns and stage hazards are different for each game difficulty.
Every stage has a miniboss.
Every stage has unique mechanisms, for the first and second half.
2 armors that can be mixed, and they unlock unique abilities for each combination.
ALL armors from X-X5 are also in the game (except Gaea armor I think).
And one boss from each X-X5 games are also included.
Skill trees drastically change the powers you get from the bosses.
Of course, side quests in the open areas.
Ride armors are also customizable.

posts.com: Can I combine 2-3 hacks in the game? Or will it break? I want Simon's quest with normal advice, double hearts and no floor traps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Sometimes it's possible, but it depends on how each patch was constructed. If one or more of them start moving data around that conflicts with the other patches it'll break. If there's no documentation about it then the only way to know for sure would be to try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Use Lunar IPS and make sure the "Create a log file" option is ticked, then check the log files and see if that no two hacks replaces the same addresses (offset + size)

in most cases if there are is no overlap then it should be compatible, unless as pointed out, one of the hacks moved data around and a change in another hack still thinks the data is in the original place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625168
Programmer decides ROM read speed, but if it is too much for the cart it returns shit instead of the expected values.
So you enable the "fast" ROM read speed (the speed used by almost if not all commercial games), you read some data from ROM and if returned values are not what you expect you are using a piece of shit cart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633459
Yeah. Gran Turismo isn't terrible impressive from a graphical standpoint, the biggest thing it had going was a more realistic physics engine than other console racing games from the era as well as a larger focus on "normal" cars alongside supercars. Kaz said that his inspiration for the first GT was basically "I want to drive my own car on the tv".

Gran Turismo 2 was where they started going apeshit and really pushing the PS1's hardware. They doubled the texture resolution on the cars to make sponsor logos on them more readable, for example. Backgrounds also got more detailed as well (the Seattle Circuit, surrounded by buildings and overpasses is a great example).

You're still limited to 6 cars on the track though (and the framerate tanks whenever more than a couple of them are on the screen), compared to something like >>9637450 that can support up to 40 cars at a time and still maintain 30fps.

Ultimately we'll never know what the Saturn was capable of, because Sega assfucked the launch and did a poor job of getting third party devs onboard, and even once they did their documentation was sparse and sometimes poorly translated, so they had to figure a lot of shit out on their own, which slowed progress.

There's a timeline out there somewhere where the Saturn got home ports of Virtua Fighter III and Daytona USA 2 and all of that, but sadly we'll never know what they looked like or how they performed.

The Quake II port is pretty good, but it's not true Quake II. The amount of levels that were cut is extreme. It is pretty impressive graphically though (even though the "skyboxes" are just textureless goraud shaded walls in the windows kek). Having four player quad splitscreen multiplayer (and having it run at a decent framerate) is also pretty impressive, even if the multiplayer levels they created for it are smaller than my first apartment.

The Saturn got a port of Quake that if I remember right maintained every level except the secret ones, which were replaced with Saturn exclusive secret levels. It is significantly closer to the PC version of Quake than the PS1 version of Quake II is to the PC version of Quake II. Saturn Quake doesn't have multiplayer though, and the framerate chugs in some areas.

Still though, both are pretty impressive. People at the time said "The Playstation can't run Quake", "consoles aren't powerful enough" etc etc, and then Quake got ported to the Saturn and Quake II got ported to the Playstation, and now Unreal has been ported to the Saturn.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9643908
Virtua Fighter 2 looks better than Tekken 3, you are smoking crack. Tekken 3 does a significantly better job of blending the 3D fighting area with the 2D background image though, I will admit that. Virtua Fighter stages have an elevated platform over a flat plane (to facilitate Ring Outs), whereas Tekken fighters stand directly on the flat plane, which scrolls infinitely. The elevated platform makes the transition looks weird in comparison. The character models and textures (as well as the resolution) are where VF2 really excels when comparing the two.

You are absolutely right on your next point though - 3D platformers were a genre that didn't see a lot of releases on the Saturn - and also what it did get was mostly ports (this is a consequence of launching in an era where arcade games were incredibly popular). Had it lasted a full generation I'm sure we would have seen quite a few hitting the system once consumers stopped being satisfied with home console ports of quick playing arcade games. "Bringing the arcade into the home" was a big deal in the mid 90s (and we were finally starting to get to the point where home console ports could be near arcade perfect or even arcade perfect), but that interest changed as gamers started wanting more in-depth games (the kind of games that detractors would call "cinematic").

The Saturn had a lot of really excellent games, but it cannot and will not ever be able to compete with the PS1 in terms of the sheer quantity of games and the variety of geners available. It's better to focus on what the Saturn does and does well as opposed to focusing on games that never made it into the library at all.

>>9647514
>its cartridge that lets you read burned games and other stuffs, but you won't be able to save on the cart, but its ok the battery is pretty good,

There are PSK carts that allow direct saving in game. I don't know why people keep repeating this nonsense.

If you have a 4-in-1 (1MB RAM, 4MB RAM, saves, and cheats) and you flash the bank that stores the cheats with the PSK firmware than your cart still works like a normal memory cart. You can even buy them pre-flashed.

The second best option for maintaining saves is to get an ODE that allows you to transfer them from the console's volatile memory to an SD card for backup.

The actual best option for maintaining saves is to do an FRAM mod for your Saturn. This replaces the volatile memory with non-volatile memory that doesn't rely on external power, so if your battery dies your saves are still fine. The replacement chips are dirt cheap, you need to have some soldering skill to do the job, but there are plenty of places online that will do it for you. You should be able to get it done for like $60-$80 (plus the cost to ship your console there and back).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sengoku Rance was the biggest for me.
I played it when I was about sixteen, never having really played an "adult" RPG before, and it totally redefined in my mind what an RPG could be.
Compared to other games in the series it's quite tame, but for a teenager, playing a game where messing up means that a character you love might get raped or killed was almost overwhelming.
What makes it special I think is that those elements aren't just there for shock value; they're building blocks of a legitimately great story.
Each of the elements― the huge stakes; the sweeping scale of the journey; the incredible amount of freedom you have; the intensely beautiful, beautifully intense soundtrack; rock-solid, legitimately challenging gameplay; and Rance, who is one of the greatest and most interesting characters in fiction― all combine and build upon each other. By the end of the game, it felt like every decision I made could change the fate of a nation and a world.
More than anything, it stopped me from ever again looking lightly upon a game just because it has porn in it. After finishing Sengoku Rance and wanting more, I was lucky enough to experience two equally incredible titles: first CROSS†CHANNEL, then Saya no Uta, and after that there was no stopping me. I would eventually go through the entire translated catalogue of the Japanese adult scene, then start learning Japanese while playing the then-untranslated Rance VI, leading to me studying to be a professional translator today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Initially watched my older brother play FF 4 and 6 on the SNES as well as Chrono Trigger, however I remember also seeing bits and pieces of Secret of Mana and probably some others I've since forgotten. When he returned home from college, we had just gotten a Playstation 1 and he saw the paltry number of games I had and wanted to show me Final Fantasy VII (as well as MGS). Needless to say, I was impressed and loved it. However, it wasn't long before I saw ads for FF8, and he wasn't around to show it to me (I think he skipped it initially as well) so I jumped at the chance to get it and to this day I love it with all my heart. I'm taken straight back to being 11 years old and thumbing through the Bradygames strategy guide, learning all about the game, inspecting the bestiary, etc.
After VIII though, I dropped off. I tried Legend of Dragoon and beat it with my dad but we both agreed that shit went on for way too long. I skipped IX because I was a dumb kid that wanted mature games for mature gamers and the kid-like appearance of the characters wasn't my jam. I did give X a try but I was ready to drop turn-based JRPGs and did. Got gifted XII and XIII and they did absolutely nothing for me. I was done.

Sadly, I totally missed out on Dragon Quest games and all the more obscure JRPGs. They just weren't put in front of my face so I never engaged with them. I could go back and play them but I don't know. The last new turn-based rpg I played was Octopath Traveler and while I mostly enjoyed my time with it, by the end I was skipping every cutscene. I never even did the optional hidden boss Galdera.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647978
>What 5 color 160×144 pixel games are you playing in current year? Does it hold up today?
Well, I've only completed 5 of all GB/GBC titles I've played, and only for 2 franchises, Spider-Man and Yu-Gi-Oh! I know that's quite random, anyways those are the ones I can talk about:

1. Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters
One of the most archaic video games I've ever played, the ammount of RNG involved, rules that are so basic it can feel downright shallow, and 100 wins requirements to get the cards everyone wants... still, I like it, the simplicity has some charm to it, the art is neat and it's the closest we'll get to a Duelist Kingdom RPG.

2. Yu-Gi-Oh! Dark Duel Stories
A lot better in both gameplay and artwork, with monsters having effects, though the rules differ from the OCG/TCG I still like them, and it's nice seeing some Yu-Gi-Oh! Forbidden Memories characters, almost as if this is the portable port, it's nice, just wish the story was more concise, there's practically none here.

3. The Amazing Spider-Man
I don't think this gets enough credit, of course the control isn't perfect, but you get used to it very quickly and, once you do, you find something that, at the time it was released, did everything people wanted, a video game where you play as Spider-Man, beat up bad guys, do some platforming and use his web, it's fine.

4. Spider-Man
A lot of interesting ideas were attempted, RPG mechanics with a lite MetroidVania progression... anyways, the control is worse than the Game Boy one, which came out a decade earlier, and the flying enemies are annoying, especially in the sewers. Not bad, but I don't go back to it, even with its excellent atmosphere.

5. Spider-Man 2: The Sinister Six
Everything a sequel should be, they took the original, polished it up, made everything better, especially the controls, which are quite satisfying here. We've lost all RPG and MetroidVania elements, but that's fine, as long as the controls and level design are good, which they are here.

Yes, the FOV in parts with pre rendered backgrounds is usually very big, with cameras far away from the characters.
This is why models are the way they are, there was no technical reason why they couldn't have used battle models outside of battles.

It is because they kept with the tradition of older FF games: all of them except 6 have closer FOV and more detailed characters in battle than they do in the world. They simply adapted that to 3D.

FF8 broke away from the tradition but as a result you have a much greater percentage of camera point of views that are closer to the characters, using scrolling backgrounds more when the characters move around.

This right here. I don't think it necessarily is a problem specific to random encounters either. It's a general problem with combat in story-centered JRPGs. What used to be the main part of the "story" in dungeon crawlers - i.e. you encounter an enemy that tries to kill you - is now turned into an obstacle that's in the way of the "real" story. By having so much linear scripted story it becomes more obvious that the random encounters aren't part of that story and it becomes just a chore you have to slog through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9636792
>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638054
The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't know if it's a story so much as a nostalgia thing but some of my earliest memories are of playing SMB 1, 3, and Battletoads with my dad. We used to get stomped by Turbo Tunnel but I'll always remember when my dad finally aced it, was mind blowing to me. Before my little brother was born it was a mix of that and watching him and my mom play 2 player on SMB 1, they were both great at it.
After that my best gaming memories are of playing multiplayer with my little bro, then Crash Team Racing came out and we racked a bunch of hours playing 4 player on that, truly a golden era. Later on me, my brother and my dad got REAL autiatic about the target flying minigame in Super Monkey Ball.
That's what it's all about bros. I don't get where all the vicious cynicism comes from, I had always assumed the people that liked retro games would understand the heart of the experience and what made it fun in the first place. Like I fundamentally don't get HATING a console for instance. I was so out of the loop in the mid 90s that when my friend down the road said he got a Playstation for Christmas I thought he was referring to some sick playground setup in his backyard. I disn't know 3D gaming was a thing until I went to my cousin's birthday and he had an N64 set up in the living room, blew my mind. He showed me Starfox, Banjo Kazooie and Mario 64 and it hit me like the spaxe baby scene at the end of 2001 Space Oddyssey.
I ended up getting a PS1 before an N64, and was somewhat sad at first but then I played Spyro and Croc and it just was magical shit man, like it saddens me that I don't think future generations will feel anything like that. Eventually got an N64 maybe a year later and it was just as cool. We had no concept of x amount of good or bad games for a console, it was just two different extremely cool things that both brought me a ton of mirth and good memories.
Tldr play games with people you love and stop being a cynic anons, don't miss the point of the whole thing.

I also had a creative writing class back in middle school. It was framed like an exam where we were given an hour and a list of prompts off which to launch our story, the one I chose was "The ship is going down!"
So naturally I turned it into a Star Wars fanfic since I'd be playing a shit ton of Republic Commando at the time. I stole characters, descriptions, and probably even plot points from the game. I remember my teacher's face as she was reading it, just absolute confusion. I think there was a moment she realised it was Star Wars and then just went "Oh" and gave me a middling mark.
I felt pretty disappointed because I'm actually an okay writer when I don't completely sperg out. I think I even did a Star Wars performance for drama class too. I wish I could go back and stop myself.

This game is good. Only retarded sodabrained Gen X boomers hate it, because they think a child character is a personal attack on their masculinity. Pathetic. Imagine getting filtered by 1 character. This was a late '96 release that was under the radar, plus making it be DK instead would cancel out the purpose of makong Dixie the star. I've been hearing the same stupid shit since the 2000s on forums about how Kiddy alone ruins the game, without really delving into what they think about the gameplay proper. Yes it is more puzzle/gimmick centric than the first 2 games but that isn't inherently a bad thing. And if they did also have similar reservations that was all superceded by "NOOOO KIDDY IS LAME FUCK KIDDY HE IS A DUMB BABY ABSOLUTELY RUINED IT". It is pure insecurity.

There is nothing wrong with Kiddy. I personally think he is a good character. The design being a retarded overgrown baby ape with retard strength is funny as hell and peak Rare humor, and he does show cheeky behavior in the game like raising his eyebrows at you or picking Dixie up like a ragdoll. He is also a return to the 1 heavy 1 agile partner dynamic of DKC1, except he is better than DK because he has a smaller frame, his jumps are more froglike and he can hold barrels in front of him. The ONLY criticism you can lob at him is that his special abilities are useless and situational (The water skipping).

>>9643979
I love it. I always have.

You must play it two player with someone who likes using the vehicle you don't use. Lot's of teamwork involved and it's very hard. Tons of weapon power ups, and deplete-able sub-weapons.

Lots of enemies and they come in fast. Hardly any slowdown. Good soundtrack, gritty 80s arcade graphics transport you back into a futuristic cold-war era.

Helicopter can dodge ground enemies, tank can dodge flying enemies, both can't dodge their shots. Helicopter can move all over fast, but can only shoot straight. Tank moves slower, and has to dodge/jump ground obstacles, but can fire in diagonal front directions.

No other game is quite like it, certainly on the SNES. It's been getting more popular, as it should. It is definitely one of the best co-op SHMUPs.

Top 5 reasons why Cave is the shittiest shmup company ever and killed the shmup genre:

In summary: Fuck Cave and may Tsuneki Ikeda burn forever in Hell.

My guess?

Some exec either looked at the box art and went "What is this baby stuff? Put yourself in the perspective of a marketing department in the 80's, in a less globalized world, the only anime kids would know are some imports like Voltron or the three series of Robotech, more cute stuff like Hello Kitty is niche.
Kids are selfconsious about cute and kiddy things, game graphics are still thought as being representational than literal(it was only a few years since home consoles were atari; no one thought the characters were meant to be literal big lobs of pixels or that the cars were literally all single colored chunks). People saw the Megaman graphics(and name) and didn't think he was literally meant to be some tiny kid, but a cool cyborg man.

posts.sub: Explaining digital vs analog inputs for games w/ digital controls
posts.com: How do I explain to my zoomer roommate, in the easiest-to-understand way possible, that using an analog stick to play a game that uses 8-direction digital control is not optimal? Don't get me wrong; how he plays his own games is none of my business. But he's convinced that an analog stick is the best choice for shmups, 2D platformers, and fighting games, and when he sees me make a mistake in one of these games, he often tells me that I'm putting myself at a disadvantage by using the d-pad, and that I'd have an easier time if I used the analog stick instead. He even suggests using an analog stick for NES games. He's pretty smug about it, despite being so wrong, and I'm tired of hearing it. But I'm bad at giving explanations. While we at /vr/ can argue forever about which digital input is best, surely we all agree that analog isn't ideal, right? I don't know how to explain to him WHY digital inputs like a d-pad are the better option, in a way that he can understand. How should I go about explaining this to him? Preferably in a way that doesn't come across as elitist or condescending.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a game designed for digital, it only accounts for 8 directions: up, down, left, right, and all 4 diagonals.
In a game truly designed for analog, there are many more small variations of those directions. So by using analog for a digital game, you lose precision as pushing the stick slightly to the upper left or all the way to the upper left leads to the same result.

Also personally I find that with a joystick you lose time as well. Going from the top left diagonal to the bottom right diagonal takes me a split second longer with a stick than with a d-pad.

But I don't know, it's very much possible that a zoom zoom has an easier time with analog still because that's all he's known all his life and he doesn't even know how to properly position his thumb on a dpad or something. I don't know how zoom zooms work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9645945
>you lose precision as pushing the stick slightly to the upper left or all the way to the upper left leads to the same result.

That's not directly harmful though. You get extra choices of what exact directional signals you'll send up the controller wire, yeah, but an ideal cyborg-person could discard all but exactly nine relevant choices and then just use those and only those, if having extra choices is the only difference between the two input devices. The extra choices are fine in themselves.

The problem is the other differences. I think the biggest one is probably the travel distance, as you say. On a d-pad, if I need to move my Tetris Attack cursor four spaces to the right or if I'm in any of the many games that let you tap right twice to run and I want to run, then I'll just gently and briskly tap on the right button a few times, because it's a button. It's very simple and natural and fast. With a stick, I need to rock my thumb weirdly, so that the stick dances across the intangible boundary between the right-direction zone and the central dead zone. If I go too far I'm wasting time and I might even fail to get my character to run. If I don't go far enough then I might miss the boundary and wiggle uselessly on one side of it, sacrificing one or more button presses entirely. It's crap, and only a fool like OP's roommate would prefer it.

>>9645608
>Easy example is how doing diagonals on d-pad can be hell on your thumb sometimes,

After thirty years of using d-pads I still haven't ever experienced whatever you're talking about. Maybe you and I touch the d-pad with different parts of our thumbs?

>>9646514
>An analog stick is nothing like an arcade stick though. An arcade stick is an 8-direction digital input just like a d-pad.
If you're using the analog stick in a game with digital input, the analog stick basically becomes an 8-direction digital input too, though with a circular gate instead of a square one. I'm not saying they're the same, but for me "analog" stick feels more intuitive coming from the arcade stick, than the d-pad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646564
OP here. See, this is what I'm talking about.
> If you're using the analog stick in a game with digital input, the analog stick basically becomes an 8-direction digital input
This is wrong. However, I will admit that I can't actually explain, in clear english, exactly why this is wrong, other than to just direct you to >>9644795 and >>9645945 . An arcade stick may look more like an analog stick than a d-pad, but functionally it's much closer to a d-pad. All that extra motion you can get with an analog stick is a waste when using it for a mere 8 directions, and this extra motion will make your inputs slower and less accurate. The posters I quoted are correct when they say that you can tap directions faster, and that these games were designed with digital control in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647565
Look, I actually agree that the d-pad is much faster. Even faster (perhaps even more so) than the arcade stick (just moving your thumb vs moving your whole hand or even your arm).

>All that extra motion you can get with an analog stick is a waste when using it for a mere 8 directions
And the arcade stick has that extra movement too. You have to move past the deadzone for the movement to register. Of course it depends on how big that deadzone is on your stick and for analog sticks I guess it depends on the game how big of a deadzone it uses.

Like I said though, I'm not saying they're the same. The arcade stick is obviously better than the analog stick (for digital input games). On the arcade stick you also get more feedback for when you're past the deadzone since you hear and kind of feel the switches activate. And I'm sure there might be other disadantages of the analog stick too, like slower input compared to digital controls. And I agree that functionally an arcade stick has more in common with a d-pad, but practically speaking, it's easier for me to use an analog stick than a d-pad. For playing fighting games for example an advantage of an arcade stick is that it's easier to perform circles and half-circles. And for me that's much easier on the analog stick too compared to the d-pad. I'm also better at doing "fluid" movements with arcade sticks and analog sticks in shmups compared to with a d-pad. But if I were to retrain myself to get more comfortable with the d-pad I'd probably play even better with that.
